The goal of our show is to educate and entertain our viewers through laughter and fast paced excitement. We want to show that armed with a little helpful information, ANYONE can get out there and truly enjoy their own camping adventure.


Online presence.
                Around the Campfire Challenge will not just be a stand-alone series. We will be launching a companion web site that will be a rapid access designed to answer any camping related questions a person may have. How do I level my trailer? We’ll have a tutorial video for that. How do I tie a Bow line knot? We’ll have an illustrated step by step guide for that.   You want a recipe for a peach cobbler, that you can cook in a cast iron pan, directly over a campfire? Oh, you better believe we’ll have a place for that! Need to know how to shave your cat, while it has distemper and hates being touched? Yeah, you may need a different web site for that one. But any topics you see covered on the show, will have detailed directions available whenever you need it. Tutorials, product reviews, camping recipes, activities, you’ll find it here.
                                              
Similar Style & Tone                            Similar Theme                       Similar Tone & Emotion
 
Why is this a marketable idea?
The unique format of Around the Campfire, allows us the ability to invite retailers and manufacturers, onto the show, where they can showcase a wide variety of innovative and trend setting gear. This is where we will bring in the bulk of our revenue.
                                                                   
                                                                   Similar in Marketability
Skills segment – The instructional segments of each episode are available for specific brands or manufacturers to have one of their representatives on screen, explaining and giving a full demonstration of their products.
Set dressings – Our set is designed with logo placement in mind. Background banners can be used to showcase branding advertisement or sponsorship on screen during challenges.
Wardrobe – Our lawyers have made this quite clear… repeatedly! “the Hosts must NOT be naked on screen” so, what better place to have them wear sponsored fashion brands when they’re on screen.
Background – The set always needs object placement, this can be simple things like an axe leaning up against a pile of wood. A knife sitting on the table, all the way up to tents and trailers in the background. All placements would be listed in the credits, as well as on our web page.
Challenges and prizes – All the objects our challengers handle within an event, are available for product placement.  All the gifts and prizes will be sponsored items.

CBC News 04/23/21
The great thing about camping is that camping is not a destination, it’s not just something you do.  Camping is a frame of mind, a feeling, it’s getting to spend time with your family without life’s stressful distractions. Sitting around a blazing campfire with a group of friends, laughing the night away, and reminiscing about days gone past. Camping is defined without boundaries: It knows no gender, belief or personal view.  Camping is something that is for EVERYONE, anywhere, any time! Around the Campfire, everyone is in love with nature!

story:
Our show is a half-hour comedy series that explores what happens when rebellious teenager, Krish Shetty, becomes the first Indian-American lifeguard at the exclusive beach town Pointe Bay. Each episode is told from the point of view of a different character at The Pointe.

In the pilot, we see Pointe Bay through the eyes of Ryan Blake, the town’s teen alcoholic and all-American misfit who makes too many crude jokes and takes way too much Adderall. When Ryan learns that Krish is stuck working there for the summer because he took a bat to his ex-girlfriend’s car, Ryan takes a liking to Krish – and Krish takes a liking to Ryan’s older sister, Sam Blake. With a knack for inviting trouble, the two piss off their boss/Sam’s boyfriend/the mayor’s son, Jason Reynolds, when they crash Jason’s summer kickoff party.

The Pointe uses laughter and storytelling from multiple points of view to explore the universal problems of race in America, gossipy small towns, loneliness, friendship, judgment, and acceptance. By the end of the pilot, you’ll be left with a sore belly and a hunger to see what the other characters think of the infamous Krish.

Thanks to the incredible support we received in our last crowdfunding campaign, The Pointe’s Pilot episode is in post-production! Now that we’ve brought the story of The Pointe to the screen, we need YOUR help to share this story with the world!



We need your support, whether it be a donation of money, time, or a post on social media. Join our team and help us spread the word. For your contributions, you will receive our eternal thanks, some unique perks, and the opportunity to be a part of something special. You can say you knew us before we were cool, and we’ll be sure to remember you when we’re famous! If you can donate even $1, or share our campaign on Facebook or Instagram, it will really help The Pointe get to the next step.

Your contributions allow us to afford:

-Post-production voiceovers and ADR (so that we sound as good as we look)

-Editing (so we can bring everything together)

-Color Correction (to help get those ocean blues just right)

-Scoring and sound design (because The Pointe's intro will be your new favorite song)

-Film & pitching festivals (because you miss 100% of the shots you don't take)

-Pitches to streaming services (so you can watch The Pointe on your favorite streaming service)

-Pitches to larger TV networks (so the entire nation can see The Pointe)

-Feedback on our pitch and pilot from industry professionals (to help us break into the room where it happens)

-Marketing for The Pointe (so we can connect with more people like you!)



The Pointe allows us to touch upon many problems our country is facing today. Some of us are Ryan Blake – stuck in a small town, struggling to keep things fresh and worthwhile. Some of us are Jason, a big fish in a small pond with big aspirations. And some of us are Krish, the outsider just trying to fit in.

Krish comes to The Pointe like an immigrant coming to America, and as many immigrants do, he makes The Pointe better with his unique life experience. At times, the inhabitants of The Pointe fail to see that. But Krish teaches our quirky cast of characters about his culture, learning to question his own judgments in the process.

By supporting The Pointe, you’re supporting independent filmmakers – and it’s not just about us. You’re showing Hollywood that diverse stories are important, valuable, and have an audience. You're showing the world that ALL points of view are important – both traditional and nontraditional. You’re helping us tell a story that we rarely get to see, one that reveals the underlying racial tension in rural areas – and has a few laughs, to boot.

With your help, we can share The Pointe with the world.

It’s tough to pitch a pilot in today’s TV world, but we are confident that The Pointe is a show worth watching. With your help, we can get our story out there and make audiences laugh until it hurts. Without your help, no matter how incredible the pilot is, our story won’t be heard.

We’ve put in countless hours over the idea, the script, and the final product. We know that the harder you work, the luckier you get in this industry – and we are willing to work hard. We just need your help to get lucky.



Strapped for cash? Even five dollars can point-e us in the right direction! If you’re unable to donate, there are other ways to help. The easiest (and most impactful) thing you can do is share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc., and then like The Pointe on social media! Just scroll up and use those nifty Indiegogo share buttons, then find us at the sites below:

http://www.thepointetv.com/

https://www.facebook.com/ThePointeTV

https://www.instagram.com/thepointetv

story:
ABOUT ME AND MYTHOS 

When people ask me where I’m from, I often hesitate to answer. That’s because I was born and raised in Venezuela and my family is from Syria. I haven’t been back home in 12 years. To be completely honest, I’m not sure what’s like to live there anymore. What is home? Is it a place? Is it a person? Is it a memory?  Similar to myself, the characters in the world of Mythos are going have to figure out what is home for them.

Mythos is an hour-long fantasy drama about a demigod who teams up with three Greek gods who are banished to our world and struggle with identity crisis as they lose the very thing that makes them gods—their immortality. Together, they will realize that they are humanity’s last hope to survive the apocalypse.

HOW YOU CAN JOIN THIS ADVENTURE 

MYTHOS is a story I feel very strongly about. I’m extremely excited to shoot and share it with you, and I’m giving my 100% to make sure it will come out in its best shape and form. 

And you can help me make sure it will find its audience. Because ultimately, the greatest story in the world only exists when it's experienced by others. 

It should go without saying that filmmaking is expensive, so to be able to bring on board the people and locations that will expand our MYTHOS universe, we need some help. 

We need $20,000 to complete production for Mythos. Your donation will go toward:

-Crew and Equipment

-Insurance

-Transportation

-Location Rentals 

-Food

-Set Design

-Wardrobe & Props 

-BTS Photographer

Asking for a monetary donation is not something easy to do, nor do I take this task lightly, so before you hit the donate button, or even if you don't, I want to thank you for supporting this project.

I hope you’ll join me in this adventure and help me make a pilot I am convinced will offer a different take on the human experience and our current state of the world. 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

If you're unable to donate for whatever reason, but still want to help support MYTHOS, there's a few ways how you can help: 

Send this campaign to your indie film-loving friends and family!  

Or donate in-kind services or skills:

BTS Photographer looking to build their portfolio.

Hair and make-up looking for IMDB credit/experience.

Etc., etc. You get the idea! =)

story:
Short Summary

I'm James Croteau, a film student based in Toronto with a passion for horror. I've always wanted to make movies, but more importantly, I wanted to make horror movies, like the ones I grew up loving. I believe that any film that can balance serious themes or dark imagery with a sense of excitement and humour is a remarkable accomplishment, and something that I strive to do myself. So after three years of film school where documentary and drama were prioritized, I've been given the freedom to finally make the kind of film that I want to make, a film that takes inspiration from the films that made me who I am today. 

Strange Aeons is the story of a detective in search of truth. After investigating a string of unexplainable disappearances, he journeys to the home of an eccentric professor who believes that an ancient cult worshipping an evil entity known as Azathoth may be responsible. Both visually and story-wise, the film is influenced by horror films of the 70's and 80's relying on bold, colourful lighting and exaggerated camera movement. 

The film is also being made largely due to the hard work and dedication of my wonderful peers, fellow film students whose passion is second only to their talent behind the camera. We've got a killer crew and this wouldn't be possible without the help of my producers, director of photography, effects team and everyone else involved.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • The film's budget is around $5500, a modest goal in comparison to other thesis films being made by my other fellow film students this year. 
  • The money goes towards renting high-quality camera equipment, securing a shooting location via Set Scouter, providing Craft Services for those working on set, and transportation for the loads of props, gear and crew members.
  • The majority of the film's costs have been paid for out of pocket by us, so any funding will go towards getting that money back. Any additional funds not going towards the actual production will be used for promotion and to help us get the film into festivals. Additionally, it will help us to make some merchandize in the form of hats, t-shirts, buttons and posters, all of which will be available as perks to those who donate! 
  • Lastly, once the film is completed, it will be available to view online to those who donate, and every supporter will get a special thanks in the film's credits.

The Impact

This film is the culmination of four years of knowledge. Film school is extremely rewarding, and while it's often challenging, the chance to create something that we are passionate about is wonderful practice for what we all hope to call a career in the future. 

Although I myself have written and directed projects in the past, this is the first time that I can do so on such a big scale. Many people are involved in the project and they are all looking to hone their skills and create something great, myself included. This film is by far the most important project most of us have ever been a part of so far.

The film itself deals with themes of hopelessness, fear of the unknown, and the grim possibility that the future may not be as bright as we once hoped. These themes, all of which are relatable for any student, will be presented in a cathartic way allowing us to not only deal with our existential worries but turn them into something tangible, something constructive and above all else, something entertaining. It is through entertainment and art that we can gain a better understanding of our fears and our lives. 

Risks & Challenges

Obviously in filmmaking, risks and challenges are plentiful. 

  • A large concern is not being able to get back the money already put into this project. As it is a student film, we make no profit. Without donations, we would all be in the hole a few thousand dollars, and with the school year coming to an end, student debts are creeping up on us faster each day. 
  • The film is getting made either way, but its quality depends on our ability to problem solve. Equipment provided by our school may be faulty, lights could burn out, camera batteries could go dead in an instant, and noise complaints may be issued from neighbours to our set. In filmmaking, anything that can go wrong usually will go wrong and we're taking this into consideration by coming up with as many back up plans as we can.
  • Locations will not fall through which is great. They've been locked down. That being said, some exterior shots may be more difficult to get, given that they are being filmed at night on public roads. This leads to a plethora of potential issues, but as stated before, filmmakers come equipped with a skill set for problem solving in the moment. 
  • The film may only be viewable online, as festivals are hard to get into. Doesn't mean we won't try though!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, you can still help us out! Please feel free to spread the good word and help us reach as many people as possible!

  • You can share our Indiegogo page on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or any other social media or online platform.
  • Spread via word of mouth! Tell all your friends and family about Strange Aeons! 

And that's all there is to it.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can share our Indiegogo page on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or any other social media or online platform.
Spread via word of mouth! Tell all your friends and family about Strange Aeons! 

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Have you ever wondered why there isn’t a quirky show about young people struggling to date and work in an urban environment with hot actors playing the idealized versions of the show’s significantly more pimply and out-of-shape creators? 

Oh, there are already are a thousand of them out there, five hundred more already in production?!

Well, how about one featuring UNIQUE and SURREAL ANIMATIONS combined with LIVE ACTION erotic historical fiction fantasies of ARIEL AND MALLIN ALTER?

Meet Myrna and Adelaide, two sisters who may or may not be based off the show’s creators, as they traverse an MC Escher-like urban landscape full of distant and high maintenance fuck-boys, work situations that rival the internecine dramas of Westeros and Essos, and a digital world that’s as nauseating as Alice in Wonderland putting on an Oculus Rift. 

SPINSTER SISTERS is co-written and directed by Mallin Alter & co-produced and animated by Ariel Alter. Because Mallin’s best at shouting at the actors to keep it sexy and Ariel’s best when hiding behind a computer, totally not cursing at a DIY budget lighting kit so we can take photos of the actors for the IndieGoGo campaign.

But, what are you doing on Indiegogo?

Good question! Unfortunately none of the funds raised are going to Mallin and Ariel's personal Maserati collection. We are raising money to actually pay our cast and crew (gasp!) in addition to renting nice equipment.

Here is our breakdown:

Cast and Crew: $2600

Equipment: $600

Here is a little bit about us, and the people playing us:

Ariel Alter is an illustrator and animator living in Echo Park. She is currently working on the westside helping create content for 13-year old boys and the 13-year old boy inside all of us. While not living a hermitic lifestyle tending to her indoor plants and kombucha cultures, she enjoys making cartoons of the jokes she makes with friends and running a private erotic dancing studio from her apartment. 

Mallin Alter is a  writer, director, and shameless theater nerd. A recent graduate from UCLA’s School of Theater, Film, and Television, she has directed productions such as “King Lear,” Chekhov’s “The Cherry Orchard,” “Never Swipe Right: A Tinder Love Story." Mallin lives in the Valley with two elderly roommates who just happened to spawn and raise her from birth. She is addicted to Bodice Rippers with a dash of royal court intrigues and betrayals.

Michelle Wicklas is from a small suburb of Los Angeles, where crippling childhood asthma forced her to forgo the outdoors and find a much safer hobby: theatre. She can be found on multiple stages in the greater Los Angeles area and is a huge advocate for the classics. She is excited to be playing an age-appropriate, non-male character in Spinster Sisters. And yeah, she loves cats.

Kelly Ohanian is a Los Angeles-based actor, originally hailing from the little state of Maryland. She proudly holds a bachelor's degree from Catholic University, where she studied musical theatre. You can probably track her down in various theatre productions and independent films around town.

And yeah, she loves cats.Kelly Ohanian is a Los Angeles-based actor, originally hailing from the little state of Maryland. She proudly holds a bachelor's degree from Catholic University, where she studied musical theatre. You can probably track her down in various theatre productions and independent films around town.

story:
HOW IT BEGAN:

I always had a passion for writing. I like to entertain people and I try to bring a smile to everyone I am surrounded by - it brings me joy every time I see someone smile or laugh. Just like thousands of other people, I am an immigrant in the United States. While juggling 2 jobs I am doing my best to make my dream come true as an Filmmaker/ Writer/Storyteller. In my journey from Nepal to South Africa to NYC, and now LA, I have so many stories to share. Recently, I started focusing more on writing so I could create content that will entertain people all around the world. 

After working on my current project for 2 years, I was inspired  by the mockumentary style of The Office ( also my favorite show), which made me realize that I could tell my story in a new and more humorous way . Upon meeting Anna-Kate Blackford at work, we became friends and I learned that she has  a degree in writing from SCAD, and had prior experience working on multiple tv shows. Soon after reading my script,  she invited me to the LA SCAD Alumni and Friends Writing Group, where I got the opportunity to learn and grow alongside fellow writers who were on the same path.

With the help of the writing group I finally started this web series. I recently filmed the pilot, which is currently in post production. I will post a teaser soon, so you can get a taste of  what I plan to bring to the world in hopes that everyone will laugh their ass off!

WHAT WE NEED:

We are looking to raise $25,000 for  a 10 episode series. This also includes fees charged by Indiegogo. Besides those fees, here is how we plan to spend the money we raise:

- Equipment rentals

- Permits and Insurance

- Paying cast and crew (Actors, Director, DP, Sound, Makeup and more)

- Props and locations

- Craft services

- Post production

If we make our goal, and this series becomes a reality, we will use any surplus funds to make either a trailer or episode for the next season.

We understand and appreciate the value of every donation we receive, and we have some exciting rewards to thank you for your contribution.

IMPACT:

This project has been made possible by our team of fellow dreamers that hustle to make creative, engaging content - while still holding down a full time job. First and foremost, your role in making this series come to life helps all of us move closer to making our side hustle our new full time job. 

In the years since I started writing my story, immigration has become a hot topic. Though it was not our goal initially, our series can help lessen the fear that surrounds people wanting to move to United States to follow their dreams. With greater understanding of the normal lives of these people, we hope we can bridge the gap with laughter and love.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

As an immigrant who works multiple jobs, I understand the value of every dollar contributed. Even if you cannot contribute financially, we always appreciate your assistance by sharing this campaign digitally, through social media, and organically, by word of mouth!

Thank you so much !!!!!

story:
A Note from the Creator

As a storyteller and as a woman, I want to explore a character who has had to make sacrifices in her life she never expected, and finally at this point, after the dust has settled of raising a child and building a home realizes that maybe this isn’t the life she expected or wanted to live. Along the way she lost the power and agency she took for granted when she was younger. I started writing this script a year and a half ago as a feature treatment but found that long-form television was the medium that would bring Mary’s story to life.

 

The pilot opens with Mary Yates on her 50th birthday at her weekly women’s club meeting. Surrounded by women her age in an opulent country club, it’s obvious that while Mary may be a member of this society she doesn’t exactly fit in. As we follow Mary through what is supposed to be a typical day in her life we catch her husband Sebastian cheating on her with none other than Christina Woods, the president of Mary’s women’s club. And to make matters worse, later that night Mary is kidnapped by a mob coming to finally collect Sebastian’s debt that he has kept secret from everyone in his life. Through these unexpected obstacles, we see Mary starting to regain a power she realized she had lost.

 

Where Your Money Goes

 

The Impact

In the approximate 300 films shot in NYU every semester, little to no emphasis is placed on sustainability. With the high scope of power, electricity and resources utilised in every shoot, each shoot leaves a significant carbon footprint. This project is a 30-minute television pilot, Mary and the Mob, produced in the Advanced Television Production class at Tisch Film, run by Assistant Arts Professor Harry Winer. The key crew of Mary and the Mob aims to implement a carbon neutral set, alongside reducing waste and reusing resources. Our goal is to become the benchmark for future productions, proving that sustainability is not only important, but also feasible.

 

Who We Are

Vivian Gisle - Showrunner

Vivian is a senior at New York University studying Film and Television. Originally from Miami, Viv has spent her time at NYU focusing on writing and working as a production sound mixer. She has worked on over 90 productions, including the Oscar-nominated short film “My Nephew Emmett.” She wants to make it very clear that no one was harmed in the making of the fundraising video, except for maybe Matt.

 

Matthew O’Connor - Director

Matt O’Connor is from Philadelphia Pennsylvania and is a senior at New York University studying Film and Television. Matt has written and directed over 50 comedy projects, and at least 3 of them have been funny. Matt hopes this pilot will make his tally an even 3 ½.

 

Heather Vaxer - Executive Producer

An aspiring producer from South Florida, Heather Vaxer is a junior at New York University studying Film and Television with a minor in Business Entertainment Media & Technology. Having produced many NYU student productions, she is excited to take on a project of this scale and bring Vivian’s vision to life.

 

Vanneeda Keowmang - Producer/Production Sound

Vanneeda Keowmang is an aspiring writer and sound designer currently enrolled in NYU Film and TV. She hails from the small island of Penang, Malaysia and still doesn’t know what a Fahrenheit is.

 

Jacob Linden - Producer/Casting Director

A Film & TV Senior from Baltimore, Maryland, Jacob is used to wearing many different hats and has gone to great lengths to explore a variety of departments in the filmmaking process through crew experience on student films, music videos, and the odd Reality TV extravaganza. Jacob’s foremost passion is working with people, whether it be by bouncing ideas around in a writers room, reaching out to and working with up and coming talent, or fighting together with peers and collaborators to produce someone’s vision. Jacob looks forward to creating Mary And The Mob with his talented classmates.

 

Stefan Nachmann - Director of Photography

Stefan Nachmann is a Brooklyn based cinematographer. He has been working on films since before he move d to the United States from Germany, working for different production companies including narrative productions and documentary projects. Since joining the NYU community less than two years ago, he has shot several intermediate and thesis projects, as well as many independent films.

 

Owen Lazur - Assistant Director

Owen Lazur hails from Minneapolis, Minnesota. His skills as an assistant director and producer stem from his varied experience in nearly every department of film production, from sound to lighting to visual effects. He has a fervent passion for story, and is attracted to projects with vivid characters and engaging drama.

 

Ramiel Petros - Line Producer

Originally from the San Francisco Bay Area, Ramiel Petros is a senior at NYU Tisch School of the Art’s majoring in film and television. He has worked on dozens of student shorts, in almost every role on set. Ramiel has interned with productions for TruTV & Amazon Studios, and worked as the Unit Production Manager on a feature film.

 

Amelia Boscov - Production Designer

Amelia, originally from Philadelphia, is a junior at NYU majoring in Film and TV. She enjoys working in the art department on sets for short films and TV shows, as well as directing her own projects. She spends most of her free time as an associate director for Fusion Film Festival.

 

Saunder Lynne Boyle - Art Director

Saunder is a Junior at Tisch majoring in Film and Television Production. She focuses on bringing stories alive both in her screenwriting work and through production design. She is thrilled have an hand in creating the glitzy, grimy, high-stakes world of Mary and the Mob as the Art Director.

 

Bradley Sachs - Sustainability Supervisor

Bradley Sachs is an Environmental Studies and Science undergraduate student at Skidmore College. He is very excited to be working on this production in to help make it more sustainable!

 

Character Breakdowns

MARY YATES (50)  - Series Lead. A housewife that could’ve been her husband’s boss if she hadn’t focused on supporting their daughter that’s now left the nest. Mary gets less and less satisfaction from her existence every day, as her social influence in the neighborhood wanes as well. She’s become used to being overlooked at the country club, but deep down yearns to take her power back.

When her husband’s infidelity and debts to the mob are revealed, this gives her the unexpected momentum to turn an accidental kidnapping into an exciting and illegal new line of business. Bossing around c-list goons turns out to be more similar to raising a child than you think.


SEBASTIAN YATES (Mid 50s) - Supporting role. Mary’s husband, who may have been a skilled businessman in his day, but nearing 60 what’s left of him is a cowardly and unfaithful shell of his former self who couldn’t remember his anniversary if it were his phone password.

Sebastian’s secret financial failings over the years have led to him resorting to Marco Woods’ Mafia family to prop up his business. Along with this web of lies, Sebastian has also been having over a year-long affair with Mary’s friend Christina, which she discovers on her birthday.

 

HAILEY YATES (25) - Supporting role. Mary’s loving daughter that’s moved from their town to go to art school in New York city. She’s blossomed into her own person in New York, and finds going home tedious. She’s fearless and independent, and fierce towards people who’ll hurt her family and friends.

Hailey takes care of her mother after she kicks out Sebastian and really needs the help, but when she goes out on her own to find her when she goes missing, she gets sucked into the illegal activity that ensues.

 

CHRISTINA WOODS (Late 40s) - Supporting role. Christina is a younger-looking friend of Mary’s who’s twice as passive aggressive. She’s the newly crowned President of the Women’s Club and has slowly taken everything from Mary’s social standing to her husband from her. She’s shallow and rather image obsessed, wants absolute control in every situation, and holds her recovering addict son to a strict schedule.

She’s afraid of her mob boss husband, Marco, and when Mary gets in business with Marco, she has Christina under her thumb because of the dirt she has on her.

 

OWEN WOODS (24)  - Supporting role. Christina’s bumbling and self-destructive son that lives back home after several stints at rehab. He’s unable to stay on the straight-and-narrow, and despite how scared he is of his mom, he’s eager to get involved in his father Marco’s criminal enterprise.

Owen’s one of the two low-level goons that botches the hit on Sebastian and kidnaps Mary instead. He’s quick to get the group in over their heads and is hardly capable at helping as the stakes rise.

 

RALPH (Mid 20s) - Supporting role. While he may be more experienced than his associate Owen in the organized crime game, Ralph is just as stupid and much more interested in hanging out with his girlfriend at any given time.

 

PETE WOODS (Late 30s) - Supporting role. Pete is the mid-level mob boss overseeing the botched kidnapping operation, and is not even fully prepared to be in charge of the minor stake of the mob business in his name. He’s good at threats and putting on a tough face, but doesn’t have the backbone or leadership skill to climb the ladder and step out of his brother’s shadow.

He’s jealous of his brother Marco’s more natural talent in organized crime world, and his attempts to prove himself only put the family business in further jeopardy. He slowly loses his position in the mob to Mary as they start working together to track down Sebastian.

 

MARCO WOODS (Late 50s) - Supporting Role. The powerful and ruthless boss of the local Mafia that intimidates anyone he crosses. His reputation for violence and brutal protection of his territory precedes him  around the whole New York Tri-State area, so he has little patience for the failings of his underlings in dealing with Sebastian’s debts. Marco hates mixing family with business.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word and share this page wherever possible!

  • Be sure to keep up with our Facebook page as we document the production process and give a closer look into our cast and crew.

story:
Please consider donating any amount (click “Back It” to begin--and don't forget to select your perk, if applicable!)

How Our Ministry Began

Since March 2020, Heidi and Mark Witte have been producing and sharing their free 30 minute Kids’ Liturgy episodes in response to the coronavirus pandemic, when many Catholic churches had to temporarily close their doors. Many families (including theirs!) searched for a way to continue planting the seeds of faith in their children. In fact, continuing their young daughter’s faith formation was the motivation for starting this ministry!

How Our Ministry Has Grown

What started out as a temporary Children’s Liturgy of the Word series for their parish instantly grew into a program watched by thousands of families from all over the world. Viewers from 6 continents have fervently shared how the weekly Kids' Liturgy YouTube videos have helped their little ones understand God’s Word and grow in faith. So many parents and DREs have noted how this program has been a lifeline during this challenging year. In April of 2020, the program was picked up by the CatholicTV Network, with the first televised episode airing on Easter Sunday. 

With family-friendly religious music by world-renowned Catholic composer John Burland, faith-based signs in American Sign Language, and abundant imagery to help bring Sacred Scripture to life, their videos encourage children to actively participate in the liturgy. Pflaum Publishing Group, a leading Catholic Publisher, graciously provided their wonderful Children’s Celebrate Leader’s Guide as a resource to help Miss Heidi convey the truths of the Catholic faith to young viewers.

Miss Heidi also began designing a free downloadable coloring page to correlate with each Sunday’s Gospel reading. Children can submit their artwork to be aired at the end of a future episode. This allows children to more actively participate in the mission of evangelization--they, too, can help spread the Good News through their art! In recent months, Kids’ Liturgy has received over 250 coloring pages per week from children around the globe! 

What's Next

Heidi and Mark give thanks to God for leading them to this ministry, which has enriched their lives in so many ways! However, making these weekly episodes has been one of the greatest challenges of their lives. Both Mark and Heidi have spent countless late nights scripting, filming, producing, and editing Children’s Liturgy videos (after their children have gone to bed and after their full-time work and home responsibilities). 

After much prayer and discernment, Mark and Heidi feel called to continue producing Children’s Liturgy of the Word episodes as well as other catechetical programming, and they are doing everything in their power to make this calling their full-time jobs. They have big aspirations of reaching more families, parishes, and Catholic schools around the world to help supplement early childhood catechesis, encourage a deeper understanding of Sacred Scripture, serve as a way for parents to become more involved in their children’s faith journey, and strengthen the faith of our little ones--who are the future of the Church! 

How You Can Help

By helping Heidi and Mark reach their campaign goal with a one-time donation, you can ensure another year of Kids' Liturgy programming, including more free episodes of Children’s Liturgy of the Word! They would be humbled by any level of support. Please consider donating any amount (click “Back It” to begin) to help their fundraising efforts. If you are not able to help financially, you can also support us by spreading the word about our Kids’ Liturgy ministry with your diocese, parish, parish school, family, and friends. The Wittes would be very grateful for your prayers, as well! God bless you for considering becoming a supporter of Kids’ Liturgy Video Ministry!

**Please note: Kids’ Liturgy, LLC is not a non-profit company. Donations are not tax-deductible. If we are unable to reach our goal, programming may be limited.**

 

About the Producers of Kids’ Liturgy:

 

Heidi Witte--also known as Miss Heidi-- is an alumnus of the University of Notre Dame ('09) and also holds an M.Ed. in Elementary Education from the Alliance for Catholic Education program at Notre Dame. She is a former Catholic school teacher and volunteer Children’s Liturgy catechist and cantor at her family’s parish (Christ the King Catholic Church in South Bend, Indiana). She is a stay-at-home mom to her two young children and works as an independent contractor for Pflaum Publishing Group.

 

Heidi’s husband, Mark Witte, films and edits all Kids' Liturgy videos. He is also a graduate of Notre Dame ('09), with his M.F.A. in Film and Television Production from the University of Southern California. Mark has nearly 10 years of experience in media production.

This allows children to more actively participate in the mission of evangelization--they, too, can help spread the Good News through their art! In recent months, Kids’ Liturgy has received over 250 coloring pages per week from children around the globe! What's NextHeidi and Mark give thanks to God for leading them to this ministry, which has enriched their lives in so many ways! However, making these weekly episodes has been one of the greatest challenges of their lives. Both Mark and Heidi have spent countless late nights scripting, filming, producing, and editing Children’s Liturgy videos (after their children have gone to bed and after their full-time work and home responsibilities). After much prayer and discernment, Mark and Heidi feel called to continue producing Children’s Liturgy of the Word episodes as well as other catechetical programming, and they are doing everything in their power to make this calling their full-time jobs. They have big aspirations of reaching more families, parishes, and Catholic schools around the world to help supplement early childhood catechesis, encourage a deeper understanding of Sacred Scripture, serve as a way for parents to become more involved in their children’s faith journey, and strengthen the faith of our little ones--who are the future of the Church! How You Can HelpBy helping Heidi and Mark reach their campaign goal with a one-time donation, you can ensure another year of Kids' Liturgy programming, including more free episodes of Children’s Liturgy of the Word! They would be humbled by any level of support. Please consider donating any amount (click “Back It” to begin) to help their fundraising efforts. If you are not able to help financially, you can also support us by spreading the word about our Kids’ Liturgy ministry with your diocese, parish, parish school, family, and friends. The Wittes would be very grateful for your prayers, as well! God bless you for considering becoming a supporter of Kids’ Liturgy Video Ministry!**Please note: Kids’ Liturgy, LLC is not a non-profit company. Donations are not tax-deductible. If we are unable to reach our goal, programming may be limited.** About the Producers of Kids’ Liturgy: Heidi Witte--also known as Miss Heidi-- is an alumnus of the University of Notre Dame ('09) and also holds an M.Ed. in Elementary Education from the Alliance for Catholic Education program at Notre Dame. She is a former Catholic school teacher and volunteer Children’s Liturgy catechist and cantor at her family’s parish (Christ the King Catholic Church in South Bend, Indiana). She is a stay-at-home mom to her two young children and works as an independent contractor for Pflaum Publishing Group. Heidi’s husband, Mark Witte, films and edits all Kids' Liturgy videos. He is also a graduate of Notre Dame ('09), with his M.F.A. in Film and Television Production from the University of Southern California. Mark has nearly 10 years of experience in media production.

story:
What is The V.V. Vlog?

The V.V. Vlog is a satirical web series that tackles the new forms of pressure that the contemporary media put on women. 

It is shot in the form of a YouTube-Channel spoof, and follows model-turned-activist Valentina Valentino educating her followers on social issues and latest trends.

In our pilot-webisode "You are What You Eat" Valentina educates her followers on how to cope with beauty standards promoted by social media.                                                                                                  With your help we can raise enough money to shoot two more webisodes: "How to be a Feminist"- which sheds a light on 'Femvertising and how multinationals use women empowerment as a cover to Pay Gap, and "#RelationshipGoals" which is the ultimate guide to get a stylish, non toxic boyfriend. 

 

The Impact

Body image, lifestyle, relationship status, social behaviour, are often cause of judgment against women; and even in a time where it seems like women are finally given a chance to speak up, it is good to wonder how much of that “freedom” is piloted by the media and multinational corporations.

We believe it's important to make The V.V. Vlog to keep up the conversation about women emancipation, to shed a light on how social media expect us to live up to unattainable standards, and finally to do all of the above while having a laugh.

 

Cast and Crew

Carlotta Morelli as Valentina Valentino

Carlotta is an Italian award-winning actress based in London. Her credits include the Tracey Ullman's Show (HBO), Tim Key's Late Night Poetry Programme (BBC Radio4), Tracey Breaks the News (BBC One), Lip Service (BBCThree), and more. The V.V. Vlog is her first work as a writer.          https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5030941/?ref_=rvi_nm

Mitchell Mullen as the Entourage

Mitchell is an American award-winning actor based in London. His credits include The New Pope (HBO), Outlander (Channel4), Genius Einstein (National Geographic), Toast of London (Channel4), Made in Dagenham (Sony Pictures Classics), A Good Year (Fox 2000 Pictures), and more.                                                                                        https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1659086/?ref_=rvi_nm

Julian Moore-Cook as The Boyfriend

Julian was born in Canada and grew up in Ireland. He trained at East 15 and his credits include Doctors (BBC One), Benidorm (ITV), Jade dragon (YouTube), Casualty (BBC One), and more.  https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5499134/

Annie Saunders- Producer

Annie graduated from Anglia Ruskin University in 2018. Since then she has produced a number of short films such as Onija and The Toilet Club which was nominated for Best Comedy at the RTS East Student Awards. The VV Vlog is her first webseries.  https://www.instagram.com/anniesaunders_producer/

Alaric Shorter- Filmmaker and Editor

Alaric is a freelance DOP, Editor, and Filmmaker. He has worked on a range of project as diverse as music videos, short films, documentaries, and high profile charity appeals for Save the Children. His client list includes Save the Children, the EU, Black Leaf Films, as well as a number of corporates.                                                                                                                   http://www.alaricshorter.com/

 Simon Ekrelius- Stylist

Simon is an award winning stylist, his work has been published in British Vogue, Elle, Dazed and many more. He is an advocate of fair trade practices and environmental awareness. Recent commissions include Channel 4/NFL, VidalSassoon, British Hairdressing Award and ITV.  https://www.imdb.com/name/nm8055482/

 

What We Need & What You Get 

Wouldn't it be fabulous if things in life came free? Well, they don't. We need to raise £3500 so that we can pay and feed our cast and crew, afford props and costume, hire equipment, submit the series to different film festivals, and secure a location that is Valentina worthy! 

So if you would like to join us in this wonderful journey by donating to the project, we have so much to offer you with our super chic, avant-garde, V.V. Vlog Perks: varying from a personal mention on Valentina's Instagram, to having a fabulous and ridiculous photoshoot with her!

 

Risks & Challenges

Although everyone involved in The V.V. Vlog has years of experience working with BBC, HBO, FOX, ITV and more, creating something from scratch is always a big financial challenge. We want to create a product of the highest possible standard, so as to showcase the great potential of this project to production companies and major broadcasts. We also want to make sure we are able to pay everyone involved for their precious time and efforts. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially to our campaign, do not despair! There is so much else you can do. Just share* the campaign on social media and tell your friends how cool this project sounds, give us a thumbs up on Facebook, and follow @therealvalentinavalentino on Instagram. The V.V. Vlog is nothing without its followers, so get on your social media and join us in this fabulous journey! 

 

*Always make sure you are using the Indiegogo sharing tools darling! ;)

story:
What is Illusional?

 “Illusional” follows the story of Dara Elliot and Tanner Poplar, two young aspiring actors who move to Los Angeles feeling ready to take on the world *and* take it by storm. Both very imaginative and optimistic individuals, the duo learns quickly that the world they imagined and the world they end up in are in fact two very different places. As a non-binary LGBT actor and a six foot tall black actress, they don’t exactly fit the molds of “traditional” stars, but they aren’t about to let that stop them! Between navigating the trials and tribulations of adulthood and managing the expectations born from their unique worldviews, they begin to learn what it truly takes to make their mark on the world.

 But what does it really take to thrive in today’s world for two young millennials fresh out of college with nothing but a dream (and active imaginations) at their disposal? Between learning how to be “real adults” and not getting kicked out of their apartment, seeking friendships and relationships that aren’t awful, and figuring out how, exactly, someone just starts acting, season 1 of “Illusional” will see Dara and Tanner navigating survival jobs, searching for love, and learning what it really takes to be seen as serious actors in Los Angeles: from their first Groupon acting class to their very first professional auditions!

Season 1 will see our heroes:

  • confronting the issues they face as people who exist outside of the norm
  • blackness and the struggles that come along with being a tall woman
  • non-binary, LGBT identity
  • learning how to be "real adults"
  • not getting kicked out of their apartment
  • seeking meaningful friendships
  • finding love! (sigh)
  • getting into a good acting class (not Groupon!!)
  • figuring out how to be seen as serious actors in Los Angeles

 

What We're Asking For

We need $40,000 to produce our next few episodes, and that's being extremely frugal and resourceful. Fortunately for us, we have an amazing team who understands that being limited in resources can sometimes be an opportunity for innovation!

Here's the breakdown of our budget and how we plan to use your contribution:

  • Creative Team 
    • Actors
    • Set Design
  • Film Crew
    • Sound Technician
    • Lighting Technician 
  • Post Production
    • Editors
    • Marketing
  • Technical
    • Lighting equipment
    • Film Equipment
    • Sound equipment
  • Production
    • Props
    • Costumes
    • Set Rentals
    • Hair/Make Up

 

 

The Impact

We sincerely appreciate your taking the time to learn more about our passion project. As underrepresented minority film makers, our main focus is ensuring we create content of the highest quality. By expressing interest in our project, you are embodying your commitment to the arts, and supporting the creative endeavors of those typically without voices. That’s huge!

With your contribution, we will be able to:

● Rent professional-grade equipment to present our story as vividly as possible

● Support our up and coming actors with full scale payments

● Acquire filming permits to legally use public property for scenes

● Compensate our hardworking, committed crew for their time and effort

● Afford the costs of post-production that come along *after* the episodes are filmed (film editing, color correcting, sound mixing) 

● Strictly follow COVID compliance requirements to ensure safety of cast and crew

● Launch ourselves into an industry that hasn’t done enough to recognize people with differences like ours

● Popularize roles for people like us and further diversify Hollywood

As we’re sure you can imagine, the act of filmmaking is not cheap, and making our own way in the film industry as divergent creators in a “status quo” world has proven to be even more difficult. That is why we depend on patrons like you for your support. With your assistance, we will be able share our unique voices and show the world that there are untold stories out there that people are interested in and want to see!

 

Our Team

 

Dara Emery is an LA transplant from Philadelphia, where she met Tanner in high school. After earning her B.A. in Theater Arts from Brown University, she spent a year in Japan, working and writing. In Los Angeles, she began acting professionally, starring in the independent film “The Year of Winter,” for which she was nominated for Best Actress at the Bare Bones Film Festival, had a supporting role in “My Sisters,” available on Amazon Prime, and starred in two other films she’s not yet allowed to talk about :).

Tanner Holley is a non-binary South Carolina native who moved to Philadelphia at 14 years old to attend the Philadelphia High School for the Creative and Performing Arts. A graduate of Colgate University and part of the Eugene O’Neill Center’s inaugural class of the National Musical Theater Institute in 2014, Tanner has spent the majority their life training and preparing for a life in the arts. Tanner starred in the award-winning micro-short “Talk To You Later” which premiered at Outfest in 2020, the short thriller “Whitetail Bucks” in 2018, and can soon be seen in the short film “Swim Free” as lead character and transgender swimmer Sarah.

 

Isue Shin is a director/DP creating work relating to identity and memory. She is an alumnus of the Telluride Film Festival Student Symposium and Visual Communications' Armed With a Camera Fellowship. Her work has been shown at the Los Angeles Independent Film Festival, Oak Cliff Film Festival, Los Angeles Asian Pacific Film Festival, and the National Film Festival of Talented Youth. Her involvement includes the PBS documentary Finding Home: A Foster Youth Story and numerous short film, music video, and commercial projects. She is currently based in Los Angeles. 

CJ Ormita is a Los Angeles based filmmaker and photographer who graduated from RISD in 2017. He is passionate about creating works that focus on LGBTQ+ narratives and voices. CJ is a Sagittarius, loves golden hour, and is always on a quest for the best mocha drink around.

Mitchell Schwartz is an independent producer from San Antonio, Texas. His focus lies in comedies that blend situational humor, character work, and heartfelt relationships.

 

 

Bella Wattles is an artist hailing from Philadelphia, PA but currently living in Silverlake, Los Angeles. A graduate of Emerson College in Boston, MA, Bella likes to spend most of her time painting, as well as working on films as a Production Designer and graphic designer.

 

Cal Passmore is originally from Glenelg, MD, but an LA native since 2018.  Over the past 6 years, he’s worked in post-production for a range of different industries that include TV, advertising, and digital. As an aspiring video editor, what keeps him motivated is figuring out how to tell stories through the moving image in the most effective way possible with every new project he’s involved in.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you love the work we’re trying to do with Illusional but can't financially contribute at this time, you can still help us by getting the word out; just use Indiegogo's social media share tools, follow us on Instagram @illusionaltheseries, or tell a friend (or seven!) about our campaign.

Thank you so much for your interest and your patronage!!

story:
WELCOME TO COMEDY LEMONADE

My name is Elizabeth Kotite. I am a comedic actress  and playwright who has been in this business 9 years now. Most of my comedy experience comes from performing with the comedy group The Nat Turner Revue doing both sketch and improv which I have been a part of for 7 years as well as my work with other comedy groups and cabarets,  In 2016, I put up my first  full length play "Misty's Plan".  It was a look at the life of a girl who had to deal with such issues as divorce, bullying, and eventually school shootings and suicide. I played the part of Misty as well as produced it. In 2017, I put up my first solo piece "Channel Surfing Through Life" based on an actual incident of cyberbullying. Recently, I decided to move on to multimedia as an outlet for my work with the help of my wonderful co director, Samantha Samant (who directed Misty's Plan). Thus, the debut of my new web show "Comedy Lemonade"

"Comedy Lemonade" is a sketch comedy/ improv based web show covering topics from hillbillies meeting mermaids to the tide pod challenge and many more. I believe we live in a world where things are depressing with way too much hate. My dream is to build a world where we can escape and turn what is now misery into joy and entertainment. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 currently we need $15,000 for editing, salaries for our wonderful cast and crew ( who work very hard and are currently performing and working for the love of the arts), and room expenses for rehearsals and shoots.  The breakdown of expenses looks like this:

 editing  6,400

 season salary for actors/crew- 6,654

room expenses- $1,954

If you do decide to donate you will receive special perks such as-  exclusive cast interviews, a special holiday compilation,  a never before seen sketch too controversial to air and more.if we do not reach the goal remaining funds will go to editing and cast/crew salaries. 

The Impact

It seems as if we turn on the TV everyday and see the same old news stories about tragedy and the same old dramas on tv and the internet. Sadly, sketch comedy and comedy generally seems to  be a dying art form. So, I decided to bring sketch back and create a show that can bring us together. So, you will have an escape from the same old thing for something new and exciting and dare I say a bit insane. Also with everything being about me... me... me. it is tiring and boring. but comedy is always open to everyone and we make fun of everything. no topic is off limits so everything is relatable to everyone and I always want this to be about us. About friends and family.

Risks & Challenges

Here's the thing. Everything in life is expensive.  Getting things together for a show like this is quite difficult. Rooms for shoots and rehearsals need to be paid for, actors/crew need to be paid, you need to pay to get things edited. it is quite difficult. Paying for rooms I have been able to manage thankfully but currently, I have a great team of crew and actors who are willing to do this for nothing until money is raised. which is why I have not only set up campaigns such as this one but have also started to create and sell merchandise. and find any way to make money as I can. I am determined more than anything to make this work. Like my other projects I do not want this to be gone and forgotten. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Now, I know some of you might not have the money to help out. I am asking for a lot. I do not want to force people to do something you can't do. if you can't contribute yourself however. please watch the show and spread the word about this to others.  Also watch and subscribe to the show and purchase swag on our tee spring site because it can not be OUR show without you. thank you.

Looking for more information or have a question? See the FAQ

I played the part of Misty as well as produced it. In 2017, I put up my first solo piece "Channel Surfing Through Life" based on an actual incident of cyberbullying. Recently, I decided to move on to multimedia as an outlet for my work with the help of my wonderful co director, Samantha Samant (who directed Misty's Plan). Thus, the debut of my new web show "Comedy Lemonade"
"Comedy Lemonade" is a sketch comedy/ improv based web show covering topics from hillbillies meeting mermaids to the tide pod challenge and many more. I believe we live in a world where things are depressing with way too much hate. My dream is to build a world where we can escape and turn what is now misery into joy and entertainment. 
 
What We Need & What You Get
 currently we need $15,000 for editing, salaries for our wonderful cast and crew ( who work very hard and are currently performing and working for the love of the arts), and room expenses for rehearsals and shoots.  The breakdown of expenses looks like this:
 editing  6,400
 season salary for actors/crew- 6,654
room expenses- $1,954
If you do decide to donate you will receive special perks such as-  exclusive cast interviews, a special holiday compilation,  a never before seen sketch too controversial to air and more.if we do not reach the goal remaining funds will go to editing and cast/crew salaries. 
The Impact
It seems as if we turn on the TV everyday and see the same old news stories about tragedy and the same old dramas on tv and the internet. Sadly, sketch comedy and comedy generally seems to  be a dying art form. So, I decided to bring sketch back and create a show that can bring us together. So, you will have an escape from the same old thing for something new and exciting and dare I say a bit insane. Also with everything being about me... me... me. it is tiring and boring. but comedy is always open to everyone and we make fun of everything. no topic is off limits so everything is relatable to everyone and I always want this to be about us. About friends and family.
Risks & Challenges
Here's the thing. Everything in life is expensive.  Getting things together for a show like this is quite difficult. Rooms for shoots and rehearsals need to be paid for, actors/crew need to be paid, you need to pay to get things edited. it is quite difficult. Paying for rooms I have been able to manage thankfully but currently, I have a great team of crew and actors who are willing to do this for nothing until money is raised. which is why I have not only set up campaigns such as this one but have also started to create and sell merchandise. and find any way to make money as I can. I am determined more than anything to make this work. Like my other projects I do not want this to be gone and forgotten. 
Other Ways You Can Help
Now, I know some of you might not have the money to help out. I am asking for a lot. I do not want to force people to do something you can't do. if you can't contribute yourself however. please watch the show and spread the word about this to others.  Also watch and subscribe to the show and purchase swag on our tee spring site because it can not be OUR show without you. thank you.
Looking for more information or have a question? See the FAQ

story:
‘I like that the series gives hope for happiness’

- Starry Mag

‘LA Web Series differs from other LGBT web series as it does not focus on the exploration of the characters' sexualities.’ 

                             - Curve Mag

‘Think 'Before Sunrise', but with queer ladies’

                                                                         - Bella Books

‘LA Web Series is for the romantic in you’ 

‘A story of falling in love the old fashioned way, LA Web Series reminds us what it’s like to be young and in love for the first time.’

                                               - AfterEllen

 ‘There is a natural ability with you interacting with each other. I don’t connect with people if they don’t connect with what they are portraying. I see that natural connection and chemistry in “LA Web Series.’

         - Starry Mag

http://www.afterellen.com/general-news/529641-la-web-series-romantic

story:
Do you like watching shows on Netflix, Hulu, or HBO, but are frustrated when series you love get canceled, network executives pick the same, "safe," tested content over and over, or your favorite shows take directions you hate?

Or are you a creator fighting endless obstacles towards working in television? With the near impossibility of breaking into the industry, you feel how hard it is to get your project seen, let alone made.

Then Candivan is for you.

Candivan is a streaming site similar to Netflix or Prime, but it’s one where viewers get to make all of the decisions. Instead of network executives deciding which shows get made and the direction those shows take, you get to pick, giving creators a chance to make shows and have them seen.

 

Why this is so friggin cool for viewers

Other streaming sites are all great, but they’re not incredibly different from Network TV. Producers make the decisions, with money, not viewers, being the bottom line.  Then there’s Youtube, which is fun and free, a wild west, but flooded with BILLIONS of videos, ranging from original, innovative documentaries to a six minute clip of a sink dripping. It’s a wonderful place to find Youtubers and cat videos, but a rough place to find quality, curated shows. A lot is also lost when an algorithm is trying to determine the best videos to show you.

Candivan is the step in between: we have curated full length running series, but it’s YOU who makes the decisions, not the producers. You pick which shows get renewed. You pick which shows receive higher budgets. And once it’s up and running, potential showrunners pitch their ideas to you.

This interactivity doesn't end with choosing shows and budgets. Many of the shows have options to participate, like voting on reality-show contestants, choosing scenarios, and even shaping plot lines. Viewers get ranks that include perks,  like being included in meetings with show casts and crews. Candivan isn't a platform where you passively watch TV; it's a platform where you're part of the show-making experience.

 

Why this is dope AF for creators

If you ever had the dream of making or working on your own TV show, Candivan wants to help make that happen. Making a show can be a nightmare, fighting against industry policies and discrimination, facing rejection after rejection, having a producer demand compromises that ruin your project, or spending your entire savings to create something that no one will see.

Anyone should have the opportunity to make a show and earn a living off of it. We give a far lower budget to produce a show than networks do, but it’s enough to create something without compromising. We have a range of shows from starter to premium ones, and we also offer mentorship to aspiring showrunners.

With any site that’s geared towards creators, the biggest problem is that when you DO happen to get your show made there’s often no audience. But Candivan plans to solve this by making this platform incredibly fun for viewers by creating many interactive in-house shows, offering lots of user choice,  and having ample opportunities to win prizes. This active experience should bring far more viewers to your show.

Candivan will take down the wall between creator and audience to be a platform where you get support and loyalty from viewers because they get to be part of the show-making experience.

 

Our Shows

We’re working with some of the most talented, up-and-coming creators, ranging from seasoned filmmakers working on passion projects (like Koji Sakai, creator of The Front Office) to new and aspiring teams like the one behind The Madams.

These are some of the shows that are going to be on our network when we launch (see our site to look at full trailers):

 

The Madams

A dark comedy about the misadventures of two sisters, Logan and Madison, as they attempt to run a secret escort service in Los Angeles. When Logan becomes a suspect in a murder at her former brothel, their new business and sisterly bond are tested.

 

The Front Office

A Shakespearean drama about a family-owned basketball franchise and the drama that ensues when the leadership switches from the father to one of his three daughters. Created by the legendary Koji Sakai.

 

The Disappointing Life of Cassie Star

Cassie Starr a former star, who after moving back to her hometown, must decide what to do with her life. She used to be on TV. She used to be on Broadway. She was in two movies. But Cassie Starr is starting to realize that she’s no longer a star and maybe never was. Starring Girl Code actress and writer Shalyah Evans.

 

Stand-Up Competition

A stand-up competition in the Bay Area where comedians are pitted against each other and viewers decide on the winners. Grand winner will have the first ever Candivan stand-up special.

 

Speed Dating

A speed dating competition where you can see different dates live, and you have full control over what you want. Viewers get to play matchmaker.

 

And much, much more.

 

Trailer for The Front Office:

 

The deal

We want to create fun, interactive shows for viewers, and opportuny and exposure for creators. We're hoping to raise $80,000. This $80k will help pay for building and hosting the site, and help fund the first set of shows to get made at launch -- which we’re aiming to do in July of 2019. 

If we hit our goal, here's what you will receive:

  • A fully functional site where you can vote for and interact with our shows
  • Four premium shows (trailers at the bottom of this page and on our website)
  • Five in-house, interactive, low-budget shows, descriptions below.
  • Levels and clubs you can join with opportunities to connect with creators/ stars and have more decision power
  • Access to some of the best independent TV shows and movies out there
  • Opportunities to submit shows and pitch ideas
  • Opportunities to view show submissions and select the shows you want to see
  • Much more

Here's exactly what we'll be doing with the $80,000:

  • $38,000 to shows, by far the most expensive piece of the operation.
  • $28,500 to the creation and maintenance of our website
  • $8,000 legal fees
  • $2,000 marketing/ advertisement
  • And the rest is Indiegogo/ platform fees

If we don't hit our goal, we will have to cut some of these things, like shows and site features. We'd hate to do this, but we want to be able to get a start no matter what.

 

Prizes

 

Who are we?

Candivan is created by Chris Blair, a founder of Endgames Improv, the most successful improv company in San Francisco, along with filmmakers Joel Lopez and Jessica Yeh, art influencers, like the Rebel Iris team, among others.

The team

       

         Chris Blair                          Jessica Yeh             Joel Lopez           Mohamad Akef

   

 

                         Austen Eberhardt             Michael Parlato                 Alice Kwong

                                              

 

The creative team

 

  Sam Worek   Brianna Bohnett  Ashlye Michelle Evan Montelongo Richard Mathera

 

               Annie MacMullan      David Prorok        Chris Griswold     Jonathan Boone  

                            

 

Uh, Candivan?

So a question we get often is “why the hell is this called Candivan?”

 

Great question! Few reasons:

 
  1. We want to elicit the same kind of excitement and sinful intrigue that you’d get from winning a ticket to Willy Wonka’s chocolate factory or from visiting Pleasure Island in Pinocchio.

  2.  

  3. The URL was available.

 

 

Partners/ Ambassadors

 

 

Please contact us at shows@candivan.com if you're interested in cross-promoting.       

 

 

 

Get on board

We’re fully confident that we can put out a platform that will be fun and revolutionize television for reviews and will provide many opportunities. This 80,000 is giving us a start to be able to do this.

Even if you can’t donate, you can still help us. We need people to spread the world. Following us on our socials and spreading the word about this campaign will help us IMMENSELY.

Thank you very much, and I look forward to seeing you on the Candivan.

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of dedicated filmmakers who are ready to bring their ideas to life!

Current team of filmmakers:

Macros Nora (Executive Producer, Director)

David Velick (Executive Producer, Writer, Director of Photography)

Tim McGahren (Co-writer)

 

We all are very excited and enthusiastic to bring this webseries to you!

What we need & how you benefit

This campaign is important to everyone involved because I believe everyone needs that one big break that will catapult their career forward and I strongly feel that this web series is just that! 

We need the funding for many aspects of production which include:

1. Paying  and feeding cast and crew

2. Wardrobe and props

3. Securing locations

4. Set design

5. Post production (such as music rights and editing)

6. Submitting to film festivals and streaming websites (e.g. Netflix).

In return, we have set up some really awesome perks that will give you a unique experience into the world of Trace such as behind the scenes content, posters for the series and also your very own copy of the series itself!

Risks & Challenges

There are always challenges to anything especially filmmaking. Some of the biggest challenges I feel we will face are:

1. Locations - There a few unique locations that may be a bit challenging securing but I have good location scouts and set designers who can find and transform the set of the needs of the script!

2. Marketing - A challenge in itself. There are so many ways to market this web series whether that's contests or pitching it to Netflix or Hulu, we will have our work cut for us but I have a lot of creative and passionate filmmakers who will do everything they can to spread the word and convince others that this series is worth their time.

Share! Share! Share!

We plan to pull off this project by utilizing every resource we have available to me and my fellow filmmakers who are just itching to start production. But the most important resource is YOU!

Tell your friends and family! Share on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc. The more people know about this web series, the better! 

The filmmakers on board with this project all want to thank you for your consideration we are very excited to give you a webseries that is truly exceptional and engaging! 

Enthuisastically,

Trace Creative team

story:
Hi folks, I'm Alan Mandic the HotRodHippie.  I produce a weekly YouTube series call, HotRodHippie.  On my YouTube channel I produce "How To", Product Review, Shop Tour, and Teaching videos. This year I am expanding and doing event coverage of the SEMA 2018 Trade show in Las Vegas, Nevada.

This T-Shirt drive is a pre-order campaign for HotRodHippie - "Drop Cars Not Bombs" T-shirts.  Proceeds from these shirts will go toward video production expense for Alan Mandic, the HotRodHippie's, Video Coverage of the SEMA 2018 Trade Show in Las Vegas, Nevada.

Videos are happening whether this campaign goes through or not.  Travel arrangements are already made, and Media Credentials have already been acquired.  This is just a T-Shirt drive since many folks have shown an interest in the new T-Shirts and could help to offset the expense of this endeavor.  


Thank you for considering donating.

The Shirts:

-Hanes Tagless Shirts - 100% Cotton

-Available from Youth XS to Adult 4XL

-Please Specify Desired Size in the comments of your pledge.

-Final T-Shirt design subject to change.  Photo is the best representation available, however manufacturing processes may result in minor alterations.

 

For Sponsorship or other Business Inquiries: Alan@HotRodHippie.com

This year I am expanding and doing event coverage of the SEMA 2018 Trade show in Las Vegas, Nevada.This T-Shirt drive is a pre-order campaign for HotRodHippie - "Drop Cars Not Bombs" T-shirts.  Proceeds from these shirts will go toward video production expense for Alan Mandic, the HotRodHippie's, Video Coverage of the SEMA 2018 Trade Show in Las Vegas, Nevada.Videos are happening whether this campaign goes through or not.  Travel arrangements are already made, and Media Credentials have already been acquired.  This is just a T-Shirt drive since many folks have shown an interest in the new T-Shirts and could help to offset the expense of this endeavor.  Thank you for considering donating.The Shirts:-Hanes Tagless Shirts - 100% Cotton-Available from Youth XS to Adult 4XL-Please Specify Desired Size in the comments of your pledge.-Final T-Shirt design subject to change.  Photo is the best representation available, however manufacturing processes may result in minor alterations. For Sponsorship or other Business Inquiries: Alan@HotRodHippie.com

story:
Short Summary

Welcome, and thank you for visiting our first Level 5 production, funding page.

This is our first, Level 5 multi-camera studio production of the year. Taking a script from the hit series Casualty. We will be reimagining it for our first assessment, under the direction of Lucy McCutcheon.  She we will be approaching this story from a stylistic approach which takes inspiration from the likes of the award winning director, David Lynch.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your support will mean we can achieve the high quality production we want, with great actors, props, costume, locations etc. With your support we can create a great show which we will be excited to share with you.

What we need funding for?

  • The amount shown is... a rather excessive amount, but that is flexible, and if we don't achieve it (which we don't expect to) we will still receive the any funding provided. Whatever money we do receive will help to ensure that we can create a high quality production, which will result in us receiving the highest grades. 
  • All money donated will go towards supporting our expenses such as set, costume, props and actors. 
  • Your contribution will be essential to our success for this production, We would be really limited without your help

With your contribution we will provide you updates concerning our progress on this project. And once it is finished, we will provide each of those who helped support this production with a link to view the final result.

The Impact

  • This Production contributes to our final grade on our course, it is therefore paramount that we achieve a high grade to support us in our future careers in Film and TV. Any support you can provide for us would be massively appreciated.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please Share! Every Donation Counts!

And that's all there is to it.
